title-group.article-title: Alleviation of high salt toxicity-induced oxidative damage by salicylic acid pretreatment in two wheat cultivars

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Biology, Faculty of Science and Art, Erzincan University, Erzincan, Turkey
2Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Atatürk University, Erzurum, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Salih Mutlu, Department of Biology, Faculty of Science and Art, Erzincan University, Erzincan, 24100 Turkey. Email: salihmutlu@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Role of exogenous salicylic acid (SA) in the antioxidative response to salt toxicity of two wheat (Triticum aestivum) cultivars (Gerek-79 and Bezostaya) was investigated. Hydroponic growth environment of 10-day wheat seedlings grown under normal conditions (22/20°C) was adjusted to 0.0, 0.25, 0.50 and 0.75 M of salt (NaCl), and then freshly prepared SA solutions (0.0, 0.01 and 0.1 mM) were once sprayed on leaves of the same seedlings. Activities of superoxide dismutase (SOD), peroxidase (POX) and catalase (CAT) were determined in fresh leaves obtained from 15-day seedlings. Treatment with SA alone increased all the antioxidant activities in Gerek-79. However, the same treatments with SA decreased the activities of CAT and SOD in Bezostaya, while increased that of POX. Salt applications alone increased the activities of POX and SOD, while decreased that of CAT in Bezostaya. The same salt applications increased the POX activity, while decreased the activities of CAT and SOD in Gerek-79. In plants under saline conditions, except 0.75 M NaCl, treatments with SA increased the activities of CAT, POX and SOD in both the varieties compared with plants applied salt alone. In plants applied with 0.75 M NaCl, however, treatments with SA decreased CAT activity. Results showed that salt toxicity caused a derangement in the regulation of antioxidant enzyme activities by decreasing CAT activity especially in both the varieties, but treatments with SA could turn back the derangement in the antioxidative enzymes caused by salt toxicity. SA can involve in increasing salt tolerance by regulating the activities of antioxidant enzymes in wheat cultivars exposed to salt toxicity.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Soil salinity is known to be a major problem among the stress factors limiting the productivity of plants, and most of the economically important crops are very sensitive to salinity (Mahajan and Tuteja, 2005). The effects of salinity (NaCl) on plants are a combined result of complex interaction among different morphological, physiological and biochemical processes (Apse and Blumwald, 2002). Its effects, for instance, can include reduced water potential, ion imbalance and toxicity and reduction in CO2 assimilation (Meloni et al., 2003). In addition, reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as superoxide (O2
·
−) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), are excessively produced during the response to salinity stress in plants, especially in salt-sensitive ones (Agarwal and Pandey, 2004; Bartosz, 1997; Mandhania et al., 2006; Sakhabutdinova et al., 2004). ROS are highly reactive and, in the absence of any protective mechanism, can seriously disrupt normal metabolism through oxidative damage to lipids, protein and nucleic acids (Bartosz, 1997). ROS are detoxified by both nonenzymatic and enzymatic antioxidant systems playing a crucial role in salt tolerance (Bartosz, 1997; El-Khallal et al., 2009). Antioxidative enzymes are the most important components in the scavenging system of ROS. Superoxide dismutase (SOD, EC 1.15.1.1) is a major scavenger of superoxide, and its enzymatic action results in the formation of H2O2. Produced H2O2 is then scavenged by catalase (CAT, EC 1.11.1.6) and a variety of peroxidases (POX, EC 1.11.1.7) (Bartosz, 1997). A correlation between a forceful antioxidant capacity and NaCl tolerance has been demonstrated in some plant species, also including wheat (Agarwal and Pandey, 2004; Azevedo-Neto et al., 2006; Hernandez et al., 2000; Mandhania et al., 2006; Sairam and Srivastava, 2002).

Search for plant growth regulators that mediate stress tolerance has been an important step for a better understanding of how plants acclimatize to adverse environmental conditions. Salicylic acid (SA), for instance, is endogenously synthesized in plant cells and acts as a hormone-like signal molecule for the activation of plant defenses (Hayat and Ahmad, 2007; Hayat et al., 2010). Previous studies have examined the role of SA in plant growth and development, flowering, ion uptake, stomatal regulation and photosynthesis (Popova et al., 1997). Several studies also supported the major role of SA in modulating the plant response to abiotic and biotic stresses such as drought (Waseem et al., 2006), salinity (Mutlu et al., 2009b; Sakhabutdinova et al., 2004), temperature (Shi et al., 2006; Tasgin et al., 2003, 2006) and heavy metal (Jamali et al., 2011). In addition, the effects of exogenous SA on antioxidant system in plants under saline conditions were studied by some researches (Agarwal et al., 2005; Azevedo-Neto et al., 2006; Dolatabadian et al., 2009; Sakhabutdinova et al., 2004). However, it is possible to find the articles including data contrary to each other about the roles on the activities of antioxidant enzymes of exogenous treatment with SA (Mutlu et al., 2009b; Shi et al., 2006; Waseem et al., 2006). For example, under salt stress, treatment with SA was effective in increasing the activities of SOD, POX and CAT in maize (Agarwal et al., 2005) and cucumber (Shi et al., 2006). In wheat seedlings, however, SA caused an increase in the activity of SOD, while a decrease in that of POX (Sakhabutdinova et al., 2004). On the other hand, some studies also determined that SA reduced the activity of all antioxidant enzymes in wheat seedlings under salt stress (Dolatabadian et al., 2009). These contradictory findings are a result of limited or inadequate number of present studies. An increase in the number of studies on the roles of exogenous SA will help us understand more clearly its role on toxicity tolerance.

The present study, therefore, aimed to determine the alleviation roles of exogenous treatment with SA on the antioxidative enzyme activities of two wheat cultivars under high salt toxicity. This study may also supply a major contribution to understand the difference in response to salt toxicity between varieties of wheat in SA-induced protection.

sec.title: Plant material and seedling growth
sec.p: In the study, as plant materials, two wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) cultivars (Bezostaya and Gerek-79) were used. Seeds of the plants were provided from Bahri Dağdaş International Agricultural Research Institute, Konya, Turkey. Before sowing, the seeds were surface sterilized for 5 min with 10:1 water/bleach (commercial sodium hypoclorite) solution and then washed five times with distilled water. The plants were grown hydroponically for 15 days in a growth chamber under controlled environmental conditions (22/20°C day/night temperature, 75% relative humidity and a photon flux density of 400 µM/m2/s photosynthetic active radiation at 16-h photoperiod). The seedlings were grown in a standard nutrient solution (Hoagland). On day 10, the hydroponic growth environments of the seedlings were adjusted to 0.0, 0.25, 0.50 and 0.75 M of salt (NaCl) and then freshly prepared SA solutions (0.01 and 0.1 mM; pH 6.5) were sprayed once on the leaves of the same seedlings. Distilled water was used to spray on the leaves of control plants. Following the applications above, the plant leaves were harvested on day 15 to determine the activities of the antioxidant enzymes (Mutlu et al., 2009b).

sec.title: Extraction of antioxidative enzymes from leaves
sec.p: Fresh leaves (0.5 g) were homogenized with a mortar and pestle in ice-cold 0.2 M phosphate buffer (pH 7) including polyvinylpolypyrrolidone. The homogenate was centrifuged at 12,000g for 15 min at 4°C. Supernatant was used to determine the activities of CAT, POX and SOD (Mutlu et al., 2009a, 2011).

sec.title: Determination of enzyme activities
sec.p: Activities of CAT, POX and SOD enzymes in the fractions were measured spectrophotometrically. CAT activity was measured by monitoring the decrease in absorbance at 240 nm in 50 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.5) containing 20 mM H2O2. One unit of CAT activity was defined as the amount of enzyme that used 1 μM H2O2/min (Upadhyaya et al., 1985). POX activity was measured by monitoring the increase in absorbance at 470 nm in 50 mM phosphate buffer (pH 5.5) containing 1 mM guaiacol and 0.5 mM H2O2. One unit of POX activity was defined as the amount of enzyme that caused an increase in absorbance of 0.01 per min (Upadhyaya et al., 1985). SOD activity was estimated by recording the decrease in optical density of nitro-blue tetrazolium (NBT) dye by the enzyme (Dhindsa et al., 1981). Reaction mixture of 3 mL contained 2 µM riboflavin, 13 mM methionine, 75 µM NBT, 0.1 mM EDTA, 50 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.8), 50 mM sodium carbonate and 0.05 mL of the supernatant. Reaction was induced by adding riboflavin solution and the placing tubes under two 30 W fluorescent lamps for 15 min. A complete reaction mixture, without enzyme, which gave maximal color, served as a control. The reaction was stopped by switching off the light and putting the tubes in the dark. A nonirradiated complete reaction mixture served as a blank. Absorbance was recorded at 560 nm, and one unit of enzyme activity was taken as the amount of enzyme that reduced the absorbance reading to 50% in comparison with tubes lacking enzyme (Mutlu et al., 2009b, 2011; Sairam and Srivastava, 2002).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All experiments were performed six times, and the average values were used for statistical analyses. Data were analyzed by analysis of variance, and means were compared by Duncan’s multiple range test at p ≤ 0.01.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: This study examined mutual and separate effects of exogenous SA (0.01 and 0.1 mM) and salt (0.25, 0.50 and 0.75 M NaCl) toxicity on the activities of SOD, CAT and POX in the leaves of Gerek-79 and Bezostaya of wheat cultivars. In the plants under control conditions, treatment with SA alone increased SOD activity in Gerek-79, while decreased that in Bezostaya (Table 1). Some researchers reported that exogenous treatment with SA could increase SOD activity in wheat (Agarwal et al., 2005; Mutlu et al., 2009b), and it was propounded that this increase could be based on either by the activation of preexisting inactive SOD or by increasing de novo synthesis of this enzyme (Sakhabutdinova et al., 2004). However, salt treatments alone stimulated SOD activity in Bezostaya, while slightly decreased (p > 0.01) that in Gerek-79 in comparison with respective controls (Figure 1). In addition, SOD activity in Bezostaya gradually increased depending on the increase in salt concentrations (0.25, 0.50 and 0.75 M). This can be an important difference in antioxidative response to salt toxicity between the two wheat varieties. The one reason for the difference in SOD activity between the two varieties in salt toxicity response can be due to that salt tolerance of the varieties is different. Because, some studies have shown that salinity increases SOD activity in salt tolerant cultivars and decreases it in salt-sensitive cotton (Gosset et al., 1994) and pea cultivars (Hernandez et al., 2000). In addition, the difference can also be ascribed to the diversity in mechanisms underlying oxidative toxicity injury and subsequent tolerance to salinity. Evidence supporting this approach can also be found in the literature. For instance, salt toxicity resulted in higher activity of SOD in plant cells (Agarwal et al., 2005; Sakhabutdinova et al., 2004), while some studies reported that it was decreased (Hernandez et al., 2000) and there was no change (Xue and Liu, 2008) in SOD activity in response to salt toxicity. SOD is a major scavenger of superoxide (O2 −) to form H2O2 and O2, and plays an important role in defense activity against the cellular damage caused by environmental stress (Meloni et al., 2003, Mutlu et al., 2009a, 2009b). The decrease in SOD activity in Gerek-79 can suggest that the reduced SOD activity or the excessive production of O2 − may be one of the fundamental factors in metabolic deterioration during salt toxicity. In the wheat varieties under 0.25 and 0.50 M NaCl conditions, treatments with SA increased (p < 0.01) the SOD activity in both the wheat cultivars in comparison with respective controls (Figure 2). In the plants under high salinity (0.75 M NaCl), however, treatments with SA stimulated SOD activity in Gerek-79, although 0.75 M NaCl alone decreased the activity in the variety (Figure 1), while did not change in Bezostaya (p > 0.01). The result implies that SA can play a significant role in response to saline conditions by regulating impaired activity of SOD by salt toxicity in wheat leaves. In accordance with our result, Sakhabutdinova et al. (2004) also found that SOD activity was induced by SA in wheat plants under salt toxicity.

caption.p: The effects of salt toxicity (NaCl) on superoxide dismutase activity in the leaves of two wheat (Triticum aestivam L.) cultivars: Gerek-79 and Bezostaya.

The effects of SA on SOD activity in the leaves of two wheat (Triticum aestivam L.) cultivars ((a) Gerek-79 and (b) Bezostaya) under salt toxicity. Means with different letters are significantly different at p < 0.01 based on Duncan’s multiple range test. SA: salicylic acid; SOD: superoxide dismutase.
The effects of exogenous SA on the activities of CAT, POX and SOD (enzyme unit per gram fresh weight) in the leaves of wheat cultivars without salt application.a

fn.p: aDifferent letters with in a column are significantly different according to Duncan’s multiple range test at p < 0.01.
SA: salicylic acid; CAT: catalase; POX: peroxidase; SOD: superoxide dismutase.

sec.p: In the present study, treatments with SA alone significantly (p < 0.01) increased CAT activity in Gerek-79 while decreased in Bezostaya, when compared with control plants (Table 1). This finding was more pronounced by 0.1 mM treatment with SA than 0.01 mM SA. Some researchers determined that the treatment with SA decreased CAT activity in tobacco, corn and wheat (Horvath et al., 2002; Srivastava and Dwivedi, 2001; Tasgin et al., 2006). In our results, a similar observation has been determined from Bezostaya cultivar of wheat (Table 1). SA is considered to decrease CAT activity by blocking a basic part of the enzyme (Raskin, 1992). However, Souza and McAdam (2001), who studied the effect of exogenous SA in barley, determined that SA increased CAT activity. This result is similar with the result from Gerek-79 cultivar of wheat. The findings suggest that CAT activity responds in different degrees to exogenous treatment with SA, depending on both its concentration and plant variety. According to current knowledge, even though the effect of exogenous SA on CAT activity has not been studied separately between salt-sensitive and tolerant varieties of a plant, our results support the hypothesis that SA may have different effects depending on the degrees of salt tolerance of plant varieties. In the salt-stressed wheat varieties, CAT activity was significantly (p < 0.01) decreased by all NaCl treatments (0.25, 0.50 and 0.75 mM) in both the varieties (Figure 3). However, in Gerek-79 cultivar, its reduction became more pronounced with increased salt concentrations. The inhibition of CAT activity by salt toxicity has been reported in many plant species and our results support the findings from previous studies (Eyidogan and Oz, 2007; Keles and Oncel, 2002; Shim et al., 2003). The decrease in CAT activity during salt toxicity can be an important breaking point in response to antioxidative system in plants. However, our result showed that in the plants exposed to 0.25 and 0.50 mM NaCl conditions, treatments with SA significantly (p < 0.01) increased CAT activity in both the varieties compared with controls (Figure 4). In terms of increasing CAT activity, treatment with 0.1 mM SA was more effective at 0.25 M NaCl, whereas 0.01 mM SA was more effective at 0.50 M NaCl. However, both the treatments with SA were not effective on the increase in CAT activity under 0.75 M NaCl (Figure 4). The results show that exogenous treatment with SA in especially an appropriate concentration can increase CAT activity reduced by NaCl toxicity in wheat. However, exogenously SA could not stimulate CAT activity at a high concentration of salt (0.75 M NaCl) even decreased.

caption.p: The effects of salt toxicity (NaCl) on catalase activity in the leaves of two wheat (Triticum aestivam L.) cultivars: Gerek-79 and Bezostaya.

The effects of SA on CAT activity in the leaves of two wheat (Triticum aestivam L.) cultivars ((a) Gerek-79 and (b) Bezostaya) under salt toxicity. Means with different letters are significantly different at p < 0.01 based on Duncan’s multiple range test. SA: salicylic acid; CAT: catalase.

sec.p: POX activity was increased by treatment with SA alone in both the cultivars compared with respective controls (Table 1). This result is consistent with results obtained from various plant species (Horvath et al., 2002; Tasgin et al., 2006). On the other hand, salt treatments alone also increased POX activity in both the varieties, in comparison with controls (p < 0.01) (Figure 5). The increase in POX activity became more pronounced in Gerek-79 with increasing salt concentrations rather than Bezostaya cultivar. This suggests that POX activity can be significantly affected by salt toxicity. Some studies reported that salt toxicity resulted in higher activity of POX in plant cells (Agarwal and Pandey, 2004; Mandhania et al., 2006; Sakhabutdinova et al., 2004). Similar to our study, Azevedo-Neto et al. (2006) showed that POX activity increased in both sensitive and tolerant cultivars of maize under saline conditions. In the study, increase in POX activity caused high salt toxicity in the wheat leaves is more conspicuous in Gerek-79, suggesting that it can be a better H2O2 scavenging ability during toxicity. In addition, when SA (0.01 and 0.1 mM) were applied to both the cultivars exposed to salt conditions, their POX activity significantly (p < 0.01) increased at especially 0.25 and 0.50 M NaCl, but in increasing the activity under 0.75 M NaCl, SA was effective on Gerek-79 rather than Bezostaya (Figure 6). In addition, the increases caused by SA were determined to be significantly higher in Gerek-79 than in Bezostaya cultivar. The results show that the exogenous SA increases more POX activity by NaCl alone in the wheat cultivars. Previous studies have reported that exogenous treatment with SA results in higher activity of POX in plant cells under salt toxicity (Agarwal and Pandey, 2004; El-Khallal et al., 2009; Mandhania et al., 2006; Sakhabutdinova et al., 2004). It is known that POX protects cells against the damaging effects of H2O2 during an oxidative-burst response under toxicity (Levine et al., 1994). Exogenous treatment with SA can undertake a significant role in the regulation of response to salt toxicity of both the wheat varieties by stimulating POX activity, even though this effect varies according to the plant varieties.

caption.p: The effects of salt toxicity (NaCl) on peroxidase activity in the leaves of two wheat (Triticum aestivam L.) cultivars: Gerek-79 and Bezostaya.

The effects of SA on POX activity in the leaves of two wheat (Triticum aestivam L.) cultivars ((a) Gerek-79 and (b) Bezostaya) under salt toxicity. Means with different letters are significantly different at p < 0.01 based on Duncan’s multiple range test. SA: salicylic acid; POX: peroxidase.

sec.p: In conclusion, exogenous SA caused a meaningful increase in all antioxidant enzymes (SOD, CAT and POX) in Gerek-79 cultivar of wheat, but it increased the activity of POX only while decreased CAT and SOD activities in Bezostaya cultivar. Salt (NaCl) toxicity decreased CAT activity in the wheat cultivars but under the saline conditions, treatments with SA could increase CAT activity in both the varieties. POX activity was increased by the treatments with NaCl in both varieties. Under saline conditions, treatments with SA could increase POX activity in both the varieties. The increases caused by SA were higher in the Gerek-79 than in Bezostaya cultivar. Salt treatments alone stimulated SOD activity in Bezostaya, while it decreased the same in Gerek-79 cultivar. Under saline conditions, the treatments with SA increased SOD activity in both Gerek-79 and Bezostaya cultivars at 0.25 and 0.50 M NaCl. Our results show that CAT, POX and SOD enzymes are involved in a range of defense reactions induced by SA in wheat plants under salt toxicity.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This work was supported by the Research Fund of Atatürk University, grant no: BAP-2003/267.
